## _Condé Nast Traveler_ Assistant Web Editor [**Molly Fergus**](http://www.cntraveler.com/contributors/molly-fergus) shares her favorite Chicago activities and things to do

## 
1. **[John Hancock Signature Lounge](http://www.signatureroom.com/Signature-Lounge/)** The Willis (née Sears) Tower is the Western Hemisphere's tallest building. But I prefer to take my friends to the John Hancock's 95th-floor Signature Lounge for skyline views. The Willis Tower charges $17.50 for admission, but settling in at the John Hancock's bar costs nothing except the price of your cocktail (around $15). Snag a table next to one of the floor-to-ceiling windows, if it's not too crowded, and spy four states: Illinois, Wisconsin, Indiana, and Michigan. Ladies, don't skip a visit to the restroom. The views are among the best in the house.


 


## 
1. **[Wrigley Field](http://chicago.cubs.mlb.com/chc/ballpark/index.jsp)** I'm a White Sox fan, so I feel like a traitor saying this, but you should snag tickets to a Cubs game. The nearly 100-year-old, ivy-lined field sits in the middle of the city, providing the sort of intimate baseball experience (and skyline views) that doesn't exist at newer ballparks. Plus, you'll see the city's die-hard sports culture on display: The Cubs haven't won a World Series since 1908, but the fans pack the stadium for pretty much every home game, even on weekday afternoons. Whether that means they're loyal or foolish depends on whom you ask.


 


## 
1. **The Beach** My coastal friends seem skeptical when I tell them Lake Michigan looks like the ocean, but it's true. Land isn't visible on the other end; the water turns Caribbean blue on sunny days; and [brave surfers](http://chicagoist.com/2010/12/06/monday_afternoon_diversion_surfing.php) head out when it's windy enough (usually in the winter). The effect is enhanced by Chicago's 26 miles of lakefront, which residents take to in droves once those nasty winters finally clear. Oak Street Beach is one of the city's most popular, but I prefer Ohio Street Beach, right by Navy Pier—the tiny strip of sand is often deserted. No matter the season, runners and cyclists should carve out time for a run or ride with the skyline at their backs.







## 
1. **[Thorne Miniature Rooms at the Art Institute](http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/thorne)** After paying your respects to _La Grande Jette_ and _American Gothic_ at the Art Institute, dedicate some time to the Thorne Miniature Rooms. The 68 dioramas re-create churches, mansions, and palaces on a one-inch-to-one-foot scale—you'll see an elaborate mini pipe organ, tiny stained glass windows, and petite foyers. As a kid, I wanted to take them all home as fancy dollhouses; as a grownup, I'm blown away by the intricate craftsmanship.


 


## 
1. **[Tribune Tower](http://www.tribune.com/)** The neo-Gothic, cathedral-like Tribune Tower—still home to the_ Chicago Tribune_ staff—is my favorite skyscraper in the city. It has spires and elaborate stonework and flying buttresses, but the niftiest details are the stones from landmarks around the world embedded in the walls. Look closely, and you'll spot 120 bits of famous places, including the Parthenon, the Taj Mahal, the pyramids, and a piece from every state.
